text: Emily Thornberry welcome there seems to
be some doubt in people's minds even now
about Labour's real attitude to brexit
can I ask you some very simple questions
first of all do you think that we should
be a member of the single market after
brexit I think we need to have the
widest possible access to the single
market after we leave the European Union
and do you accept given that everything
that the European leaders have been
saying and people here as well but that
means we could not have control over
immigration
I think that's subject to negotiation
and I think that we need to be
reasonable about it and we need to think
quite carefully about what the trade-off
is our priority is the economy and we
need to make sure that whatever
decisions are made we don't make
ourselves poorer and we don't take away
anybody's jobs because I mean you say
that there should be a negotiation but
for a lot of people there seems to be a
very little very little gap between
being inside the single market and
accepting free movement of people and
being outside your colleague Diane
Abbott has said you cannot have access
to the single market or be part of a
single market without freedom of
movement I think a lot of people would
agree with that and she goes on it's
time people started acknowledging that
those of us who are arguing for the
least harmful brexit have to be clear to
people that there is no deal to be done
on freedom of movement and to imperil
our economic interests as you were
saying as a country because if
anti-immigrant feeling could scarcely be
responsible do you agree with that yeah
I agree
absolutely so in the end if we're not
part of the single market if we are
going to be part of the single market
who they have access to the single
market we are going to have to concede
control over freedom of movement we
can't have both things I think that we
can I think that David Cameron missed a
fantastic opportunity to look at
reforming one of the pillars of the
European Union before we know when he
before the general election before we
have the referendum he went off and was
going to fix the European Union and yet
the European saw him coming they saw
that he wasn't acting on behalf of the
whole of Britain and he got nothing you
know and that it seemed to me to be a
golden opportunity that was wasted I
think that we have common cause with
other people across Europe in terms of
exactly what freedom of movement of
workers means and I think there's war
work that could be done if it was done
in an atmosphere of good faith but quite
frankly the way in which Boris Johnson
is behaving at the moment he's
undermining any good
that could possibly be with our European
friends and neighbors I'm still slightly
confused the kind of access that you
want to the single market and lots of
businesses agree with you comes at the
price of conceding free movement of
people do you accept that because that's
what Diana saying and she's right yeah I
think that what we need to do is to look
at what freedom of movement of workers
means and and how it is defined and how
it is applied and I think there is quite
a lot of room for manoeuvre in there
I think the David Cameron tried to do it
but was simply not in the right place
and also where we could get to them so
for example we could look at what is the
definition of a worker at what stage you
need to be looking for work how long you
can be in the country without being able
to find where I'll be allowed to come in
here people would still be able to come
in here and then there would be the
question of in what circumstances could
they find work you know in what areas of
the country might they be able to find
work there are a whole range of options
that are available and all subject to
negotiation but we are so far away from
that you know the government has
absolutely no time at all at the moment
I'm trying to work out where where labor
would like to be as it were post brexit
so you're not going to stop it happening
you're going to allow article 50 to be
triggered and you'll get a vote for
article 15 and be triggered and then
after that you're trying to get maximum
access to European markets and that
might mean very large numbers of
European workers still being able to
come and work here in exchange for
access to those markets our first
priority is the economy well the first
priority of any government should be the
safety and security of people the second
priority of any government should be the
economy because if the economy does
badly it is people who are only just
managing who will suffer and we have to
bear that in mind when making decisions
about the future of our country for the
sake of our kids and for our
grandchildren that is our biding
principle now how that works out is
subject to negotiation and at this stage
it seems to ask that the government
ought to be confident enough to be able
to come to us and say these are the
vague these are the main principles on
which we are going because they do at
the moment yeah we want our cake and eat
it we want access to the single market
and we want some kind of control over
immigration what about the customs union
for it notes it is about time we stopped
talking about leaving in cake having our
cake and eating our cake we have to look
have the options and we have to know
that it is a trade-off and then we need
to be able to have a proper debate
within the British public as to what the
options are we need to have a long term
relationship with Europe and we need to
be honest about what that means now do I
think that too many people at the moment
come into this country I think that yes
I think they do I think they do because
I think that we have a skills shortage
we are not training enough people in
this country now why is it dependent
less immigration under a Labour
government is just well it's because we
need to address the skills gap and if we
address the skills gap we won't have
same need for more people coming in do
we have employers who take advantage of
sucking people in from other countries
and undercutting wages and undercutting
conditions yes we do and we need to be
able to control that as well and it
seems to me that if we were to address
those problems properly if the employers
were finally actually training some of
these some of our youngsters
so they did have the skills I get it
listen can I ask you about one other
thing that's come up this week which is
both John Major and Tony Blair have said
that if things are as bad economically
as they may be as some of the official
reports the OPR is suggesting then there
should be a second referendum so people
can have a second chance do you agree
with that or not I think that we need to
take this in stages and at the moment we
cannot even have a debate as to how it
is that we're going to leave the
European Union because the government
are the soap that claim they're keeping
their cars to their chests but we know
they don't have any cards and they don't
even know what game they're playing and
it is about time they came out of their
darkened room and they told us in what
way we're going to leave the European
Union and what our continuing
relationship is likely to be so that we
can debate it and so the reason may if
you didn't go to Europe and say I'm
representing the whole of Britain they
need to act on behalf of a hundred
percent and not on behalf of extreme 5%
of the 52% but if you don't like what
they say when they finally government
tell us if you don't like the the vision
they have what then happens can you stop
them in Parliament you try to stop them
in Parliament in some way do you think
there should be a second referendum as a
break what then happens so that you can
get your way and they don't get their
way I think this needs to be taken step
by step but they will not take the first
step which is they have had five months
now five months you know David Cameron
specifically told the civil service not
to look at a plan B they now have had
five months to work out what their plan
going to be and they come with nothing
that is the starting point let us start
with what it is the government wants to
negotiate and then we could have a
reaction from the public and a proper
debate and then we can decide how we
want to proceed but until they actually
lay down then the goes their basic
negotiating position we cannot even
begin this debate your leader and your
friend jeremy corbyn's said of fidel
castro that he was a great fighter for
social justice and a huge historical
figure and a lot of people thought he'd
failed to address the dark side of the
Castro regime all those killings the
abuse of gay people are the torture and
so forth what is your view I think that
Castro was a hugely divisive figure and
I think that it's quite difficult to get
beyond the human rights abuses but my
own experience I went to Cuba in the
early 1990s when there was a great
economic difficulties in that country
and I found a country that was a Galit
Aryan with a fantastic health service I
had my baby with the way you had to go
off and see the doctor and it was we
were really struck by a but a heck of a
pro it came at a price but it was a Brit
right in my view it was a brave Island
that stood against a a regime that for
50 years would not trade with it and
would not let other countries trade with
it - and not only did they stand firm
and strong they they also exported their
values across South of South America and
into Africa producing doctors and easy
pass for the camps the torture I mean
this came at a huge price if it was
Pinochet people on the Left would say he
was in a monster he was terrible he
should be got rid of but because he had
wore a red star on his fatigues and so
forth you seemed to be quite gentle on
him yeah and if you look at some of the
right-wing press that we're supporting
Pinochet they're the ones who come out
and and accuse Castro of all the things
that they do let me just put this to you
how can it be that a little island like
Cuba can have not only sufficient
doctors and nurses to be able to look
after the people of Cuba that they can
also export them across South America
and into Africa to be to give more
doctors to fight about the rola crisis
than the Americans and that little tiny
country could do that and we can't how
how can you how can you can have set
that alongside for instance
machine-gunning people in boats
including children when they are trying
to leave the country I mean
how do you make this kind very hard to
make a kind of equal sign or an
equivalent sign between the dark side
and the bright side of Cuba there is a
bright side but there's a very very dark
side I acknowledge that I acknowledge
that but all I'm saying is that from my
experience my experience was visiting a
country that was at the time they didn't
have enough petrol to be able to drive
cars they were going around on bicycles
on the May Day Parade but nevertheless
there were not people starving and there
and they still have an excellent health
and an education service I'm not saying
any more than that but it was an
enormous achievement for a little
Caribbean island final thought very very
quickly you heard Steven Doral there
talking about the crisis and social care
do you agree with him and with Paul
Masson that we're going to see a crisis
that's gonna run out through the rest of
this year and do you think the chance
that she'll be back in the House of
Commons putting more money into social
care absolutely absolutely I was in
warwickshire yesterday and people are
desperately worried about what is going
to happen you know what will happen with
their elderly relatives will they be got
up at breakfast time or will they be got
up at lunchtime what will happen with
people going in into hospital in crisis
and not being able to come out again you
know for every pound we sit and we spend
on Social Care we say two three four
five in the National Health Service with
